Chapter 278
City Housing Commission



278.01   Continuation.



278.02   Membership; compensation; expenses.



278.03   Meetings; rules; record; quorum; officers and employees.



278.04   Powers and duties.



278.05   Interest of members or employees in contracts.



278.06   Annual report.



278.07   Deeds, contracts, leases and purchases.



   CROSS REFERENCES



   Dilapidation and nuisances - see CHTR. § 12.02



   Municipal housing commissions - see M.C.L.A. §§ 125.653 et seq.



   Adoption, promulgation and publication of rules - see M.C.L.A. §
125.694b



   Acquisition and maintenance of housing projects - see M.C.L.A. §§
125.731 et seq.



   Fair housing - see GEN. OFF. Ch. 624



278.01  CONTINUATION.



   The City Housing Commission, heretofore established pursuant to Act 18
of the Public Acts of 1933 (Ex. Sess.), as amended, is hereby continued. 



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94.)



278.02  MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION; EXPENSES.



   In accordance with Section 4 of Act 18 of the Public Acts of 1933 (Ex.
Sess.), as amended, the City Housing Commission shall consist of five members
to be appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the City Council. Members
are not required to be residents of the City. Each of said members shall
serve for a term of five years and until his or her successor shall be
appointed for staggered terms. Members shall serve without compensation, but
shall be reimbursed for any actual and necessary expenses incurred in the
performance of their duties.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94; Ord. 441.  Passed 12-5-06.)



278.03  MEETINGS; RULES; RECORD; QUORUM; OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES.



   The City Housing Commission shall meet at regular intervals, said
meetings to be public. It shall adopt its own rules of procedure, and shall
keep a record of the proceedings. Three members shall constitute a quorum for
the transaction of business. A President and Vice-President shall be elected
by the Commission. The Commission may appoint a Director who may also serve
as Secretary, and such other employees or officers as shall be necessary. The
Commission shall prescribe the duties of all of its officers and employees
and may, fix their compensation. The Commission may, from time to time as
necessary, employ engineers, architects and consultants.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-19-94; Ord. 441.  Passed 12-5-06.)



278.04  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   The City Housing Commission shall have the following powers and duties:



   (a)   To determine in what areas of the City it is necessary to
provide proper sanitary housing facilities for families of low income and for
the elimination of housing conditions which are detrimental to the public
peace, health, safety, morals and/or welfare.



   (b)   To purchase, lease, sell, exchange, transfer, assign and
mortgage any property, real or personal, or any interest herein, or acquire
the same by gift, bequest or under the power of eminent domain; to own, hold,
clear and improve property; to engage in or to contract for the design and
construction, reconstruction, alteration, improvement, extension, and/or
repair of any housing project or projects or parts thereof; to lease and/or
operate any housing project or projects.



   (c)   To control and supervise all parks and playgrounds forming a
part of such housing development, but may contract with existing departments
of the City for operation or maintenance of either or both.



   (d)   To establish and revise rents of any housing project or
projects, but shall rent all property for such sums as will make them
self-supporting, including all charges for maintenance and operation, for
principal and interest on loans and bonds, and for taxes.



   (e)   To rent only to such tenants as are unable to pay for more
expensive housing accommodations.



   (f)   To call upon other City departments for assistance in the
performance of its duties, but said departments shall be reimbursed for any
added expense incurred therefor.



   (g)   Such other powers relating to said housing facilities project
as may be prescribed by ordinance or resolution of the City Council or as may
be necessary to carry out the purposes of the Act.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94; Ord. 441.  Passed 12-5-06.)



278.05  INTEREST OF MEMBERS OR EMPLOYEES IN CONTRACTS.



   No member of the City Housing Commission or any of its officers or
employees shall have any interest directly or indirectly in any contract for
property, materials or services to be acquired by said Commission.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94.)



278.06  ANNUAL REPORT.



   The City Housing Commission shall make an annual report of its
activities to the City Council and shall make such other reports as the City
Manager may from time to time require.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94.)



278.07  DEEDS, CONTRACTS, LEASES AND PURCHASES.



   All deeds, contracts, leases or purchases entered into by the Housing
Commission shall be in the name of the Housing Commission.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94; Ord. 441.  Passed 12-5-06.)



Chapter 280
Local Officers Compensation Commission



280.01   Establishment.



280.02   Purpose.



280.03   Membership.



280.04   Terms of office.



280.05   Filling of vacancies.



280.06   Compensation; expenses.



280.07   Organization; meetings.



280.08   Determination of salaries.



280.09   Precedence of chapter.



   CROSS REFERENCES



   Compensation of Mayor and Council - see CHTR. § 2.04



   Compensation and salaries in home rule cities - see M.C.L.A. §§
117.3, 117.5, 117.17, 117.19, 117.20, 117.28, 117.32, 117.33



280.01  ESTABLISHMENT.



   There is hereby established, in and for the City, a Local Officer's
Compensation Commission for the City pursuant to Act 8 of the Public Acts of
1972, as amended, being Section 5C of Section 117.5 of the Compiled Laws of
1948, as amended, State of Michigan.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94.)



280.02  PURPOSE.



   The purpose of the Local Officers Compensation Commission is to
determine the salaries of all local elected officials.  The Commission may
at the request of the Mayor act as an advisory commission in recommending
salaries for the appointed officers of the City of Ionia. 



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94.)



280.03  MEMBERSHIP.



   The Commission shall consist of five members, who are registered
electors of the City, who shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to
confirmation by a majority of the City Council.  However, no member or
employee of the legislative, judicial or executive branch of any level of
government or member of the immediate family of such member or employee shall
be eligible to be a member of the Commission.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94.)



280.04  TERMS OF OFFICE.



   The members of the Local Officers Compensation Commission shall be
initially appointed as follows:



   One member for a term of five years;



   One member for a term of four years;



   One member for a term of three years;



   One member for a term of two years;



   One member for a term of one year.



   Annually, thereafter, the Mayor, with the approval of the Council,
shall appoint one member of said Commission for a term of five years. 
Members shall be appointed before October 1 of the year of appointment.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94.)



280.05  FILLING OF VACANCIES.



   Vacancies occasioned by removals, resignations or otherwise, shall be
reported to the City Council and shall be filled for the remainder of the
unexpired term in the same manner as original appointments.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94.)



280.06  COMPENSATION; EXPENSES.



   The members of the Local Officers Compensation Commission shall receive
no compensation, but shall be entitled to their actual and necessary expenses
incurred in the performance of their duties.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94.)



280.07  ORGANIZATION; MEETINGS.



   Immediately after their appointment, the members of the Local Officers
Compensation Commission shall meet and organize by electing one of their
members Chairperson and electing such other officers as they may deem
necessary.  They shall also have the power to adopt such by-laws and
regulations as they deem necessary for the carrying on of the business of the
Commission. 



   A majority of the members of the Commission shall constitute a quorum
for conducting its business.  However, the Commission shall take no action
or make determinations without a concurrence of a majority of the members
appointed and serving on the Commission.



   The Commission shall meet for not more than fifteen session days in
1973 and every odd-numbered year thereafter.  A "session day" means any
calendar day in which the Commission meets and a quorum is present.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94.)



280.08  DETERMINATION OF SALARIES.



   The Local Officers Compensation Commission shall have the power to and
shall determine the salaries of all elected officials of the City.  The
determination of said salaries shall become effective thirty days after being
filed with the City Clerk, unless rejected by a vote of two-thirds of the
City Council.  In case of such rejection, the existing salary shall
prevail.  The Commission shall make its determination within forty-five
calendar days of its first meeting.



   The Commission shall not be responsible for review, approval or
accounting for routine expense allowances or other expenses paid to elected
officials in addition to salary.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94.)



280.09  PRECEDENCE OF CHAPTER.



   This chapter shall supersede and take precedence over all existing
Charter provisions and other provisions of the Codified Ordinances relating
to either the fixing of salaries of elected officials and/or establishing a
procedure for the fixing of said salaries.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94.)



Chapter 282
Downtown Development Authority



282.01   Determination of necessity.



282.02   Establishment; powers, duties and authority; boundaries.



282.03   Downtown Development Authority Board.



282.04   Director; bond.



   CROSS REFERENCES



   Municipal bonds - see M.C.L.A. §§ 117.4a, 117.4b, 117.4e, 117.4g,
117.5, 117.14a, 117.35a



   Improvements in home rule cities - see M.C.L.A. §§ 117.4d et seq.



   Business area redevelopment projects - see M.C.L.A. §§ 125.981 et seq.



   Department of Economic Expansion - see M.C.L.A. §§ 125.1201 et seq.



   Economic Expansion Council - see M.C.L.A. § 125.1207



   Regional Economic Development Commission - see M.C.L.A. §§ 125.1231
et seq.



   Economic development corporations - see M.C.L.A. §§ 125.1601 et seq.



   Downtown Development Authority - see M.C.L.A. §§ 125.1651 et seq.



282.01  DETERMINATION OF NECESSITY.



   It is hereby determined to be necessary and in the best interests of
the public to halt property value deterioration and increase property tax
valuation where possible in the Business District of the City, to eliminate
the causes of that deterioration and to promote economic growth, by
establishing and providing for the operation of the City of Ionia Downtown
Development Authority, pursuant to Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975, as
amended.



(Ord. 283.  Passed 5-5-81.)



282.02  ESTABLISHMENT; POWERS, DUTIES AND AUTHORITY; BOUNDARIES.



   The City of Ionia Downtown Development Authority is hereby established
pursuant to Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975, as amended. The Authority
shall have all powers, duties and authority prescribed in said Act, as the
same may from time to time be amended. The Authority's boundaries within the
City shall be as follows:



   Being a part of the City of Ionia, Michigan described as:  Commencing
at the Northeast corner of Lot 2 of Smiths Addition to the City of Ionia for
the place of beginning; thence West to the Northwest corner thence South
along the East line of N. State Rd. to the centerline of vacated Mills St.,
thence East along the centerline of Mills St. to a point in line with the
West line of Lot 10 of Mills Second Addition; thence South to the Southwest
corner of Lot 10; thence East to a point 130 ft. West of the West line of
Hall St.; thence North 128 ft.; thence West 43.25 ft. to the centerline of
Mills St. (as vacated); thence North along the centerline of the N-S Mills
St. to the intersection of the E-W vacated Mills St.; thence Northwest to a
point which is 378 ft. North of the intersection of the South line of Section
18, T7N, R6W and 11.5 Rods West of the West line of Hall St.; thence East
parallel to the South line of said Section 18 to a point on the centerline of
Hall St., thence South along the centerline of Hall St. to the centerline of
Lincoln Ave. (State Hwy. M-21); thence East along the centerline of Lincoln
Ave. to the centerline of Dexter St. (State Hwy. M-66); thence South along
the centerline of Dexter St. to a point in line with the North line of Lot
142 of Supervisor Voelker's Add.; thence West along the North line of Lot 142
to the Northwest corner; thence South along the West line of Lots 142, 140
and 139 to a point on the South line of Lot Line of Lot 139, said point being
205 ft. West of the Southeast corner of Lot 139; thence South along the West
line of Lot 135 to the Southwest corner; thence East along the South line of
Lot 135 a distance of 50 ft.; thence South to a point on the South line of
Lot 134 at a point 50 ft. East of the Southwest corner; thence South 26 ft.;
thence West 50 ft. to a point on the West line of Lot 131; thence South along
the West line of Lots 131 and 130 to the Southwest corner of Lot 130; thence
East along the South line of Lot 130 to a point 132 ft. West of the Southeast
corner of said Lot 130; thence North parallel with the East line of Lot 130
to a point 13 ft. South of the North line of Lot 130; thence East parallel
with the North line of Lot 130 to the East Line of Lot 130; thence South
along the East lines of Lots 130, 126, 125 and 124 of Supervisor Voelker's
Addition to the Northeast corner of Lot 1 of Lovell and Dye's Addition;
thence South along the East line of Lot 1 to the Northeast corner of Lot 8;
thence West to the Northwest corner of Lot 8; thence South along the West
line of Lot 8 to a point 1/2 way between the Northwest and the Southwest
corner of said Lot 8; thence East 14 ft; thence South parallel with the West
line of Lot 8 to a point on the South line of Lot 8; thence South to the
Northwest corner of Lot 9; thence South along the West line of Lots 9 and 10
to a point 58 ft. North of the Southwest corner of Lot 10; thence West

282.03  DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY BOARD.



   (b)   The City of Ionia Downtown Development Authority shall be
under the supervision and control of the Downtown Development Authority
Board, consisting of the Mayor of the City of Ionia and eight members
appointed by the Mayor, subject to approval by the City Council.  At least
five of the members shall be persons having an interest in property located
in the downtown district.  At least one of the members shall be a resident
of the downtown district, if the downtown district has 100 or more persons
residing within it.  Of the members first appointed, two shall be appointed
for one year, two for two years, two for three years, and two for four
years.  A member shall hold office until the member's successor is
appointed.  Thereafter, a member shall serve for a term of four years.  An
appointment to fill a vacancy shall be made by the Mayor for the unexpired
term only.  Members of the Board shall serve without compensation, but shall
be reimbursed for actual and necessary expenses.  The Chairperson of the
Board shall be elected by the Board.



   (c)   Before assuming the duties of office, a member shall qualify
by taking and subscribing to the constitutional oath of office.



   (d)   The Board shall adopt rules governing its procedure and the
holding of regular meetings, subject to the approval of the City Council. 
Special meetings may be held when called in the manner provided in the rules
of the Board.  Meetings of the Board shall be open to the public.



   (e)   Pursuant to notice and an opportunity to be heard, a member of
the Board may be removed for cause by the City Council.  Removal of a member
is subject to review by the Circuit Court.



   (f)   All expense items of the Authority shall be publicized
monthly, and the financial records shall always be open to the public.



(Ord. 283.  Passed 5-5-81.)



282.04  DIRECTOR; BOND.



   (g)   The Downtown Development Authority Board may employ a Director
who, before entering upon the duties of his or her office, shall take and
subscribe to the constitutional oath, and shall furnish bond, by posting a
bond in the penal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000) payable to the
Authority for the use and benefit of the Authority, approved by the Board and
filed with the City Clerk.



(Ord. 283.  Passed 5-5-81.)

Chapter 286
Local Development Finance Authority



286.01   Determination of necessity; purpose.

   CROSS REFERENCES



   Business area redevelopment projects - see M.C.L.A. §§ 125.981 et seq.



   Department of Economic Expansion - see M.C.L.A. §§ 125.1201 et seq.

et seq.

   Economic and Social Opportunity Act - see M.C.L.A. §§ 400.1101 et seq.



   Downtown Development Authority - see ADM. Ch. 282



286.01  DETERMINATION OF NECESSITY; PURPOSE.



   (a)   The City Council hereby determines that it is necessary for
the public welfare of the City to create a local development finance
authority pursuant to Act 281, which shall operate to eliminate the
conditions of unemployment, underemployment and joblessness and to promote
economic growth in the City.



(Res. Unno.  Passed 5-26-93.)



286.02  ESTABLISHMENT.



   (a)   The City hereby establishes a public body corporate pursuant
to Act 281, which shall be and shall be known and exercise its powers under
the title of the "Local Development Finance Authority of the City of Ionia"
("the Authority").  The Authority may adopt a seal, may sue and be sued in
any court of this State and shall possess all of the powers necessary to
carry out the purpose of its corporation as provided by this chapter and Act
281.  The enumeration of a power in this chapter or in Act 281 shall not be
construed as a limitation upon the general powers of the Authority.



(Res. Unno.  Passed 5-26-93.)



286.03  DESIGNATION OF AUTHORITY DISTRICT.



   (a)   The property described in Section 286.08 is hereby designated
as the Authority District (the "Authority District").



(Res. Unno.  Passed 5-26-93.)



286.04  BOARD OF DIRECTORS; CHAIRPERSON; RULES.



   (a)   The Authority shall be under the supervision and control of a
Board of Directors (the "Board").  The Board shall consist of ten members,
seven of whom shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to approval by the City
Council, one of whom shall be appointed by the County Board of Commissioners
of the County of Ionia, and two of whom shall be appointed by the chief
executive officer of the North LeValley School District.  Of the members
first appointed, two of the members appointed by the City Council and one of
the members appointed by the School Districts shall be appointed for a term
of four years, the members appointed by the County and two of the members
appointed by the City Council shall be appointed for a term of three years,
one of the members appointed by the City Council and one of the members
appointed by the School District shall be appointed for a term of two years,
and two of the members appointed by the City Council shall be appointed for a
term of one year.  After the first appointment, each term of a member shall
be for a duration as provided in Act 281.  A member shall qualify for and
hold office as provided in Act 281.  The Chairperson of the Board shall be
elected by the Board.  The Board shall adopt rules of procedure governing
its procedure and the holding of regular meetings consistent with the
provisions of Act 281.  The rules of procedure shall be subject to the
approval of the City Council.



(Res. Unno.  Passed 5-26-93.)



286.05  POWERS.



   (a)   Except as specifically otherwise provided in this chapter, the
Authority shall have all powers provided by law subject to the limitations
imposed by law and herein.



(Res. Unno.  Passed 5-26-93.)



286.06  FISCAL YEAR; ADOPTION OF BUDGET.



   (a)   The fiscal year of the Authority shall begin on July 1 of each
year and end on June 30 of the following year, or such other fiscal year as
may hereafter be adopted by the City Council.



   (b)   The Board shall prepare a budget annually and shall submit it
to the City Council for approval in the manner and at the time determined by
Council, which budget shall contain the information required by Council and
shall be prepared in the manner required by Council.  The Board shall not
finally adopt a budget for any fiscal year until the budget has been approved
by the City Council.  The Board may, however, temporarily adopt the budget
in connection with the operation of any improvements which have been financed
by revenue bonds where required to do so by the resolution authorizing the
revenue bonds.



   (c)   The Authority shall submit financial reports to the City
Council at the same time and on the same basis as departments of the City are
required to submit reports.  The Authority shall be audited annually by the
same independent auditors auditing the City and copies of the audit report
shall be filed with the City Council.



286.07  TERMINATION.



   (a)   Upon completion of its purposes, the Authority may be
dissolved by the City Council.  The property and assets of the Authority,
after dissolution and satisfaction of its obligations, shall revert to the
City.



(Res. Unno.  Passed 5-26-93.)

CHAPTER 288
Parks and Recreation Commission



288.01   Commission established.



288.02   Composition; compensation; term; vacancies.



288.03   Removal from office.



288.04   Organization.



288.05   Annual report.



288.06   Functions.



   CROSS REFERENCES



   Parks - see S.U. & P.S. Ch. 1062



288.01  COMMISSION ESTABLISHED.



   A Parks and Recreation Commission is hereby established to serve in an
advisory capacity to the City Council, the City Manager and the Parks and
Recreation Services in the city and to propose rules and regulations
governing their programs and facilities for adoption by the City Council.



(Ord. 498.  Passed 2-5-13.)



288.02  COMPOSITION; COMPENSATION; TERM; VACANCIES.



   (a)   Composition. The Parks and Recreation Commission shall consist
of five (5) members who represent a broad range of interests beneficial to
the city’s parks and recreation programs. One member shall be a member of
the City Council as selected by the City Council. The four (4) appointed
members shall be appointed by the Mayor, confirmed by the City Council and
shall represent, insofar as is possible, a broad range of interested
beneficial to the city’s parks and recreation programs. Persons appointed
to the Parks and Recreation Commission shall be qualified electors of the
city, except that one (1) member may be a non-qualified elector who resides
outside the municipal boundaries of the city. An employee of the city shall
not be eligible to serve as a member of the Parks and Recreation Commission.



   (b)   Compensation. All members of the Parks and Recreation
Commission shall serve without compensation.



   (c)   Term. The term of each appointed member shall be three (3)
years or until a successor takes office. The term of the member of the City
council shall coincide with the Councilmember’s term on the City Council.
Initially, terms shall be staggered so that approximately one-third of the
members terms expire each year.



   (d)   Vacancies. Vacancies occurring otherwise through the
expiration of term shall be filled for the unexpired term by the Mayor,
subject to the approval of the members of the City Council.



(Ord. 498.  Passed 2-5-13.)



288.03  REMOVAL FROM OFFICE.



   Members of the Parks and Recreation Commission shall be subject to the
removal powers of the Mayor for failure of performance.



(Ord. 498.  Passed 2-5-13.)



288.04  ORGANIZATION.



   (a)   Officers. Members of the Parks and Recreation Commission shall
elect a chair, vice-chair and secretary at its first meeting of each calendar
year. The chair shall preside at all meetings of the Commission. The
vice-chair shall serve in the absence of the chair. The secretary shall
record the minutes of all meetings. The secretary need not be a member of the
Commission. The Commission shall adopt rules to govern its procedures.



   (b)   Quorum and Voting. Three (3) members of the Parks and
Recreation Commission shall constitute a quorum. The affirmative vote of a
majority of the members present shall be required to take action on any
matter.



   (c)   Meetings. The Parks and Recreation Commission shall meet a
minimum of four (4) times annually at the Armory Community Center, or such
other public place in the city.



(Ord. 498.  Passed 2-5-13.)



288.05  ANNUAL REPORT.



   The Parks and Recreation Commission shall prepare an annual written
report concerning the operations of the Parks and Recreation Commission and a
synopsis of its activities for the preceding year. The annual report shall be
presented to the City Council during the second quarter of the calendar year.



(Ord. 498.  Passed 2-5-13.)



288.06  FUNCTIONS.



   The functions of the Parks and Recreation Commission shall be as
follows:



   (a)   To be an advisory commission to the City Council, the City
Manager and the Parks and Recreation Director.



   (b)   To annually review, in conjunction with the Parks and
Recreation Director, the parks and recreation capital improvement plan
prepared by city staff and make recommendations to the City Manager as part
of the budget preparation and submittal process.



   (c)   To annually review, in conjunction with the Parks and
Recreation Director, the parks and recreation fee schedule as prepared by
city staff and make recommendations to the City Manager as part of the budget
preparation and submittal process.



   (d)   To develop a broad variety of facilities and services to meet
the needs of residents wishing to utilize community resources relating to
parks and recreation services.



   (e)   To inform and update the public about the purposes and needs
for parks and recreation services in the city.



   (f)   To coordinate opportunities for the public to be involved in
the planning and development of the city’s parks system and recreation
services.



   (g)   To seek out and plan the use of public and private financial
resources needed to enhance and expand the existing park system and
recreation services.



   (h)   To act as a liaison and to provide coordination with other
agencies to ensure a total cooperative community effort in providing
delivering recreation services.



   (i)   To provide encouragement and support to, and work in
partnership with, parent-led groups which deliver recreation services in the
community.



(Ord. 498.  Passed 2-5-13.)



TITLE TEN – Judiciary



   Chap. 290.  District Court



Chapter 290
District Court



EDITOR'S NOTE:  Violations of City law are prosecuted in the Ionia County
District Court (Judicial District 64A).  Equitable remedies are pursued in
courts of competent jurisdiction. 



There are no sections in Chapter 290.  This chapter has been established to
provide a place for cross references and any future legislation.

Chapter 410
Michigan Vehicle Code



410.01   Adoption by reference.



410.02   Reference to local authorities.



410.03   Publication of notice.



410.04   Enforcement.



410.05   Application to Ionia Free Fair Grounds.



410.99   Penalty.



   CROSS REFERENCES



   Traffic rules and regulations in home rule cities - see M.C.L.A. §
117.4h



   Traffic rules and regulations generally - see M.C.L.A. §§ 257.601 et
seq., 257.634 et seq.



   Uniform Traffic Code - see M.C.L.A. §§ 257.951 et seq.



   Fees in the Traffic Code - see ADM. 214.02



410.01  ADOPTION BY REFERENCE.



   The Michigan Vehicle Code, M.C.L. 257.1 through 257.923, as amended, is
hereby adopted by reference.



(Ord. 09-2005-04.  Passed 11-1-05.)



410.02  REFERENCE TO LOCAL AUTHORITIES.



   Reference in the Michigan Vehicle Code to "local authorities" shall
mean the City of Ionia.



(Ord. 09-2005-04.  Passed 11-1-05.)



410.03  PUBLICATION OF NOTICE.



   The City Clerk shall publish this chapter in the manner required by law
and shall publish, at the same time, a notice stating the purpose of the
Michigan Vehicle  Code and the fact that a complete copy of the Code is
available to the public at the Clerk's office for inspection, or is available
online at the Michigan legislature's website.



(Ord. 09-2005-04.  Passed 11-1-05.)



410.04  ENFORCEMENT.



   The Director of Public Safety shall enforce the provisions of this
chapter.



(Ord. 09-2005-04.  Passed 11-1-05.)



410.05  APPLICATION TO IONIA FREE FAIR GROUNDS.



   All streets, alleys, highways and public thoroughfares located in the
Ionia Free Fair Grounds shall be governed by the provisions of the Michigan
Vehicle Code adopted in Section 410.01.



(Ord. 09-2005-04.  Passed 11-1-05.)



410.99  PENALTY.



   The penalties provided by the Michigan Vehicle Code are hereby adopted
by reference, provided, however, that the City may not enforce any provision
of the Michigan Vehicle Code for which the maximum period of imprisonment
exceeds ninety-three days.



(Ord. 09-2005-04.  Passed 11-1-05.)



CHAPTER 420
Bicycles, Skateboards and Rollerskates



420.01   Definitions.



420.02   Application of Michigan Vehicle Code to bicycles.



420.03   Riding bicycles on sidewalks.



420.04   Bicycle license required.



420.05   Bicycle registration and license requirements.



420.06   Term of bicycle license.



420.07   Bicycle license fee.



420.08   Disposal or sale of bicycle.



420.09   Loss of bicycle tag.



420.10   Impounding of bicycles.



420.11   Second-hand bicycle dealers.



420.12   Skateboarding and roller skating.



420.13   Enforcement of chapter.



420.99   Penalty.



   CROSS REFERENCES



   Traffic rules and regulations in home rule cities - see M.C.L.A. §
117.4h



   Traffic rules and regulations generally - see M.C.L.A. §§ 257.601 et
seq., 257.634 et seq.



   Uniform Traffic Code - see M.C.L.A. §§ 257.951 et seq.



   Bicycle fees - see ADM. 214.02(a), (b)



420.01  DEFINITIONS.



   The definitions contained in the Michigan Vehicle Code, as adopted in
Chapter 410, shall apply in the interpretation of this chapter.



420.02  APPLICATION OF MICHIGAN VEHICLE CODE TO BICYCLES.



   Every person riding a bicycle upon a street or highway shall be granted
all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the
driver of a vehicle under the Michigan Vehicle Code, as adopted in Chapter
410, except as to those provisions which by their nature can have no
application.



420.03  RIDING BICYCLES ON SIDEWALKS.



   No person shall:



   (a)   Ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a Business District.



   (b)   Disobey any sign erected on any sidewalk or street which
prohibits the riding of bicycles thereon.



   (c)   When riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, fail to yield the right
of way to any pedestrian or fail to give an audible signal before overtaking
and passing such pedestrian.



(1975 Code § 10.43)



420.04  BICYCLE LICENSE REQUIRED.



   No person shall operate a bicycle upon any street, sidewalk or other
public place in the City without first having registered such bicycle and
secured a license therefor.



(1975 Code § 10.44)



420.05  BICYCLE REGISTRATION AND LICENSE REQUIREMENTS.



   (a)   Application for registration and licensing of a bicycle shall
be made by the owner in writing, in duplicate, upon blank forms furnished by
the City Clerk.



   (b)   Such application shall be signed by the owner.  The
application shall state the full name and address of the owner of the
bicycle, the name of the manufacturer, the serial number of the frame
thereof, the approximate date when the owner obtained title thereto and, if
not new, when obtained, and the name and address of the person from whom it
was obtained.



   (c)   After the issuance of the registration card and tag, the City
Clerk shall endorse upon the application and the duplicate the date of
issuance and the number thereof.  The original application will be kept on
file in the office of the City Clerk, and the duplicate thereof shall be
delivered to the Chief of Police and shall be kept on file in his or her
office.  A cross index shall be kept for the Clerk's file, providing
identification by the owner's name, bicycle serial number, and license
number. 



(1975 Code §10.45)



420.06  TERM OF BICYCLE LICENSE.



   Licenses issued under this chapter shall be effective until the bicycle
is transferred.



420.07  BICYCLE LICENSE FEE.



   The fee for the issuance of a license hereunder shall be as established
from time to time by Council and shall be payable at the time of filing the
application for a license with the City Clerk.



420.08  DISPOSAL OR SALE OF BICYCLE.



   When any bicycle which has been registered and licensed as herein
provided, is sold, or is otherwise disposed of, the new owner shall register
his or her name and address with the City Clerk, shall pay a fee as
established from time to time by Council and shall provide the Clerk with
reliable proof of ownership, which shall consist of a bill of sale, former
registration card or written statement, signed by the prior owner.



420.09  LOSS OF BICYCLE TAG.



   The licensee shall report immediately, to the City Clerk, the loss or
destruction of the tag of the licensee and the circumstances surrounding the
loss or destruction thereof.  The City Clerk shall thereupon issue a tag
upon the payment of a fee as established from time to time by Council.



420.10  IMPOUNDING OF BICYCLES.



   (a)   Authority to Remove Bicycles.  Members of the Police
Department are hereby authorized to remove bicycles from a public place to a
place of safety, under the circumstances hereinafter enumerated.



      (1)   When any bicycle is reasonably believed to be stolen.



      (2)   When any bicycle has been left unattended upon any
public street, alley, or sidewalk continuously for a period of forty-eight
hours, or when any bicycle is left in such a manner as to obstruct
unreasonably the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic on any public
street, alley or sidewalk.



(1975 Code § 10.50)



   (b)   Notice.  When a bicycle is impounded under the provisions of
this section and the Police Department knows or is able to ascertain the
owner thereof, the Police Department shall, within a reasonable period of
time, give and cause to be given a notice in writing to such owner of the
fact of impoundment and the reasons therefor. 



(1975 Code § 10.51)



   (c)   Fee.  No impounded bicycle shall be discharged or removed
from the Bicycle Pound except upon the payment by the owner or his or her
authorized representative of the an impounding fee to be determined from time
to time by Council, provided, however, that no such fee shall be required for
a stolen bicycle if it is reclaimed by the owner within three days of being
notified of the impoundment and if said owner signs an affidavit that the
bicycle is stolen.  Said fee shall be paid at the City Clerk's office.



(Adopting Ordinance)



   (d)   Sale.  Any bicycle impounded under the provisions of this
section may, after one month from the date of impoundment, be sold by the
Police Department at public sale in the same manner as provided by law. 



(1975 Code § 10.53)



420.11  SECOND-HAND BICYCLE DEALERS.



   Any person in the City of Ionia who engages in the purchasing and
selling of second-hand bicycles shall be subject to the following provisions:



   (a)   He or she shall keep a book to be inspected by the Chief of
Police or his or her representative, in which shall be written, at the time
he or she shall receive any bicycle by way of purchase, trade-in or
otherwise, or at the time he or she shall sell any bicycle, a description of
the bicycle, as to make, color, serial number, whether a man's or a lady's
bicycle and other distinguishing features thereof, and the name, residence
and general description of the person from whom the bicycle was received or
to whom the bicycle was sold.  Such book and the place where such business
is carried on, and all articles of property therein, shall be subject to the
examination at any time by any police officer of the City.



   (b)   He or she shall make a report of each purchase, trade-in or
sale containing the information required in subsection (a) hereof upon a form
which shall be furnished by the Police Department for that purpose.  The
filing of such report shall be made with the Police Department within
forty-eight hours from the time of sale, trade-in or purchase of any
second-hand bicycle.



   (c)   In the event no serial number appears on said bicycle, the
dealer shall present said bicycle to the Police Department, who, after having
made a thorough inspection of said bicycle and an investigation as to the
ownership thereof, shall stamp a serial number on said bicycle.



   (d)   When the transferee of a bicycle is a dealer who holds the
same for resale, the transferee shall not be required to obtain a new
registration and license, but such transferee shall retain and have in his or
her immediate possession, at all times, the endorsed registration card and,
upon transferring his or her interest to another person, shall endorse
thereon the name and address of the new owner and shall deliver the same to
the person to whom such transfer is made.  The new owner shall then follow
the procedure as hereinabove set forth.



(1975 Code §10.54)



420.12  SKATEBOARDING AND ROLLER SKATING.



   (a)   Definitions.  As used in this section:



      (1)   "Rollerskates" and "street skates" mean either a pair of
small wheels near the toe and another pair near the heel of a shoe or frame
that would attach to a shoe, or in-line skates, which are used for gliding on
a hard surface such as a floor, sidewalk, etc.



      (2)   "Skateboard" means an item consisting of a short, oblong
board with a pair of small wheels at each end, ridden on a hard surface such
as a floor, sidewalk, etc.



      (3)   "To roller skate" means to skate on any type of
rollerskates or street skates.



   (b)   Compliance Required.  No person shall roller skate or ride a
skateboard within the City without complying with this section and any and
all other applicable ordinances and statutes.



   (c)   Yielding to Pedestrians.  Whenever any person is roller
skating or riding a skateboard upon a sidewalk or other paved surface
intended for use by pedestrians, such person shall yield the right of way to
any pedestrian and shall not approach, overtake or pass such pedestrian in a
reckless or careless manner, nor pass such pedestrian except in single file
if such person is roller skating or riding a skateboard with other such
skaters or riders.



   (d)   Skating or Riding on Certain Devices or Structures.  No
person shall roller skate or skateboard on any public bench, table, planter
wall, retaining wall or other device or structure which is not intended for
pedestrian or vehicular traffic, or jump or step on or off such devices or
structures in the process of roller skating or riding a skateboard.



   (e)   Reckless or Dangerous Skating or Riding.  No person shall
roller skate or ride a skateboard on any sidewalk or other paved surface
intended for pedestrian use or for the parking of vehicles in a reckless or
careless manner, nor in a manner which is likely to result in injury or harm
to any person or property.



   (f)   Skating or Riding on Private Property Without Permission.  No
person shall roller skate or ride a skateboard on private property without
first obtaining permission of the owner of said property to allow such
skating or riding.



   (g)   Skating or Riding While Attached to Vehicles.  No person
shall roller skate or ride a skateboard while either the rollerskates, the
skateboard or the person is attached to any vehicle upon any street or
highway.



   (h)   Prohibitions on Public Streets and in the General Business
District.  No person shall roller skate or ride a skateboard on public
streets.  No person shall roller skate or ride a skateboard on public
sidewalks in the 100, 200, 300 and 400 blocks of West Main Street.



420.13  ENFORCEMENT OF CHAPTER.



   This chapter may be enforced by issuance of traffic violation notices.



(1975 Code § 10.55)



420.99  PENALTY.



(EDITOR'S NOTE:  See Section 202.99 of these Codified Ordinances for the
general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)



   Minors violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of
this chapter shall be dealt with in accordance with Juvenile Court law and
procedure.



CHAPTER 430
Commercial and Heavy Vehicles



430.01   Truck routes.



430.99   Penalty.



   CROSS REFERENCES



   Traffic rules and regulations in home rule cities - see M.C.L.A. §
117.4h



   Traffic rules and regulations generally - see M.C.L.A. §§ 257.601 et
seq., 257.634 et seq.



   Uniform Traffic Code - see M.C.L.A. §§ 257.951 et seq.



   Fees in the Traffic Code - see ADM. 214.02



   Transporting garbage and rubbish - see S.U. & P. S. Ch. 1060



430.01  TRUCK ROUTES.



   (a)   All trucks having more than three axles and weighing in excess
of 8,000 pounds gross weight are hereby required to use those streets and
roadways designated as truck routes in this section while being operated
within the City, unless exempted by this section.



   (b)   The following streets and roadways are hereby designated as
truck routes:



      (1)   Steele Street.



      (2)   Depot Street.



      (3)   Kidd Street.



      (4)   Beardsley Street.



      (5)   Main Street between Yeomans Street and Kidd Street.



      (6)   Main Street between Second Street and Prairie Creek.



      (7)   State Street between Lincoln Avenue (M-21) and the north
City limits.



      (8)   Lincoln Avenue (M-21) between the east City limits and
the west City limits.



      (9)   Dexter Street (M-66) between Lincoln Avenue (M-21) and
the south City limits.



      (10)   Adams Street between Dexter Street (M-66) and Jackson
Street.



      (11)   Jefferson Street from Railroad Street to the south end
of Jefferson Street.



      (12)   Jackson Street from Lincoln Avenue (M-21) to the south
end of Jackson Street.



      (13)   Jefferson Street from Lincoln Avenue (M-21) to the
north City limits.



      (14)   Railroad Street between Jackson Street and Mill Street.



      (15)   Webber Street between Jackson Street and Jefferson
Street.




      (16)   Washington Street between Dexter Street (M-66) and Kidd
Street.



      (17)   Cleveland Street between Main Street and the south City
limits.



      (18)   Main Street between Cleveland Street and the east City
limits.



   (c)   In addition to those street listed above, Bayard Street
between Cleveland Street and Mill Street shall be a limited truck route. 
Hours for Bayard Street shall be the hour preceding and following the opening
of school, lunch hour of school and dismissal of school.



   (d)   Special mobile equipment, emergency vehicles, public utility
vehicles and any vehicle, truck or equipment owned or operated by the City or
working under the direction of the City shall be exempt from this section.



   (e)   Trucks conducting business at the Ionia County Memorial
Hospital, 479 Lafayette Street, shall be exempt from this section.



   (f)   A police officer shall have the authority to require any
person driving or in control of any truck proceeding over a truck route or
street over which truck traffic is permitted, to proceed to any public or
private scales for the purpose of weighing and determining whether or not the
weight restrictions, as set forth in subsection (a) hereof, have been
complied with.



   (g)   This section shall not prohibit the operation of trucks upon
any street which has not been designated a truck route where such use is
necessary to conduct business at a destination point inside the City,
provided, however, that streets upon which such truck traffic is permitted,
as set forth in subsection (b) hereof, are used until reaching the
intersection nearest to the destination point.



   (h)   Notwithstanding any provisions contained herein to the
contrary, the Public Safety Department, upon application, may exempt any
truck from this section for any reasonable period of time. 



(Ord. 353.  Passed 8-16-92.)



430.99  PENALTY.



   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter, for which no
penalty is otherwise provided, is responsible for a civil infraction and
shall be subject to the penalty provided in Section 202.99(b) of these
Codified Ordinances.



CHAPTER 440
Parking



440.01   Definitions.



440.02   Parking within the Downtown District.

440.10   Odd/even parking.

440.12   Blocking a driveway.



440.13   Not parking within parking spaces.



440.14   Parking in an alley.



440.15   Parking in front yard and on/over a sidewalk.

440.17   Parking for a prohibited purpose.



440.18   Authority of the Public Safety Director.



440.99   Penalty; impounding.



   CROSS REFERENCES



   Traffic rules and regulations in home rule cities - see M.C.L.A. §
117.4h



   Traffic rules and regulations generally - see M.C.L.A. §§ 257.601 et
seq., 257.634 et seq.



   Parking generally - see M.C.L.A. §§ 257.672 et seq.



   Uniform Traffic Code - see M.C.L.A. §§ 257.951 et seq.



   Municipal violations in counties of 100,000 or more - see M.C.L.A. §
725.301



   Fees - see ADM. 214.02 (c),(d),(e)



   Off-street parking and loading - see P. & Z. Ch. 1282



440.01  DEFINITIONS.



   As used in this chapter:



   (a)   "Holiday," as used on the parking instruction, means only
those legal holidays as established by the State of Michigan on which a
majority of the business places in the parking zones are closed for the
transaction of business.  These shall include New Year's Day, Memorial Day,
Independence Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day.



   (b)   "Downtown District" means the Central Business District of the
City and is commonly referred to the area bound by Dexter Street on the west,
Washington Street on the north, Adams Street on the south and Library
Street/Church Alley on the east.



   (c)   "Residential District" means all areas within the City not
within the Downtown District.



   (d)   "Parking" means the standing of a vehicle upon any street or
public place, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the
purpose of and while actually engaged in loading and unloading passengers or
when obeying traffic signals or regulations.



   (e)   "Parking lots" means those lots owned, leased, under option to
purchase, or contracted for by the City, on which vehicles are parked.



   (f)   "Vehicle" means any device by which any person or property may
be transported upon a highway.



(Ord. 349.  Passed 12-3-91; Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.02  PARKING WITHIN THE DOWNTOWN DISTRICT.



   Enforcement.  The enforcement of parking regulations in the Downtown
District shall generally be in accordance with the following parameters.



   (a)   Parking may be enforced in the downtown area beginning at 8:00
a.m. and ending at 5:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday.



   (b)   Parking hours in the Downtown District will not be enforced on
holidays or Sundays as specified in this chapter.



   (c)   Enforcement shall include the following:



      (1)   Washington Street;



      (2)   Main Street;



      (3)   Adams Street;



      (4)   Steele Street;



      (5)   Kidd Street;



      (6)   Depot Street;



      (7)   Hudson Street;



      (8)   Library Street; and



      (9)   Public parking lots located with the Downtown District.



   (d)   Parking enforcement shall be made by the Director of Public
Safety or his or her designee(s).



(Res. 09-2001-05.  Passed 9-4-01; Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.03  DOWNTOWN DISTRICT PARKING REGULATIONS.



   Time Limits.  When signs limiting parking are present in proximity to
a space or lot marked for parking in the Downtown District, no person shall
park a vehicle in excess of the time period on the sign as established by the
official signs in such District.



   (a)   Thirty-minute parking.  West side of Kidd Street between
Washington Street and Main Street.



   (b)   Two-hour parking.  The following streets are hereby
designated as two-hour parking zones:



      (1)   Main Street (both sides) from Dexter to Library Street.



      (2)   Steele Street (both sides) from Washington Street to
Adams Street.



      (3)   Depot Street (both sides) from Washington Street to
Adams Street.



      (4)   Kidd Street east side from Washington Street to Main
Street and both sides from Main Street to Adams Street.



      (5)   Library Street (both sides) from Main Street to
Washington Street.



      (6)   Washington Street from Steele Street to Library Street.



      (7)   The following City parking lots:



         A.   The parking spaces located along the east side of
the Armory Community Center parking lot;



         B.   The Steele-Adams or Knights of Columbus parking
lot, except for the ten hour parking spaces located along the south side of
the parking lot;







 



         C.   The parking spaces in the large City parking lot
north of Adams Street as identified in the drawing below.



         D.   The Depot-Adams parking lot (located at the north
east corner of Depot and Adams Streets), except for the ten hour parking
spaces located along the south side of the parking lot.



   (c)   Ten-hour parking.  The following areas are hereby designated
as ten-hour parking zones:



      (1)   The parking spaces located along the south side of Adams
Street between Dexter Street and Steele Street.



      (2)   The Depot parking lot (located along the south side of
Adams Street and contiguous to the former railroad depot).



      (3)   The Steele-Adams or Knights of Columbus parking lot, but
for the two hour spaces located along the north side of the lot.



      (4)   The Depot - Adams parking lot (located at the north east
corner of Depot and Adams Streets), except for the two hour parking spaces
located along the north side of the parking lot.



      (5)   The Steele-Washington parking lot (east and west sides).



      (6)   The spaces in the large City parking lot north of Adams
Street as identified in the drawing below.







 



      (7)   Hudson Street (both sides) from Main to Adams.



      (8)   The parking spaces located along the west side of the
Armory Community Center parking lot.



(Ord. 349.  Passed 12-3-91; Res. 09-2001-07.  Passed 9-4-01; Ord. 448. 
Passed 4-10-07; Ord. 511.  Passed 5-6-14.)



440.04  RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT PARKING REGULATIONS.



   (a)   When signs prohibiting or limiting parking to a specific time
period are erected in proximity to a space marked for parking in any
Residential District, no person shall park a vehicle in that space if parking
is prohibited or if parking is limited, park in excess of the time period as
established by the official signs in that area.



   (b)   The City Council shall, by resolution, establish time limits
and fines for the various parking areas within the City.



(Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.05  TAMPERING WITH PARKING SIGNS.



   No person shall deface, tamper with, break or impair any parking sign
installed pursuant to the provision of this section.



(Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.06  ERASURE OR REMOVAL OF CONTROL MARKS OR DEVICES.



   No person shall intentionally erase or remove any mark or device placed
on any vehicle for the purpose of enforcing provisions of this chapter.  A
violation of this section shall be a civil infraction.



(Ord. 349.  Passed 12-3-91; Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.07  OVERTIME PARKING.



   No person shall cause, allow or permit any vehicle registered in the
name of, or operated by, such person, to be parked overtime or beyond the
period of legal parking time, as shown on the signs limiting parking time
posted in the district. 



(Ord. 349.  Passed 12-3-91; Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.08  PARKING ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.



   No person shall park any motor vehicle on any private property in the
City without the express or implied consent, authorization or ratification of
the owner, holder, occupant, lessee, agent or trustee of such property.  A
complaint for a violation of this section shall be made by the owner, holder,
occupant, lessee, agent or trustee of such property.



(Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.09  LOADING\UNLOADING PERMITS. (REPEALED)



   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  Section 440.09 was repealed by Ordinance 462,
passed October 7, 2008.)



440.10  ODD/EVEN PARKING.



   Except when necessary to avoid a conflict with other traffic, or in
compliance with law, or at the direction of a public safety officer or
traffic control device, no person shall park a vehicle on or along the side
of any street, within the City, with odd building numbers on an even numbered
date of the month, or the side of any street in the City with even building
numbers on an odd-numbered date of the month, during the months of December
thru March, inclusive, and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m.,
provided that this section shall not apply to that portion of any street
marked or posted, on either or both sides, with permanent parking
prohibitions. 



(1975 Code § 8.25)  (Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07; Ord. 529.  Passed 3-7-17.)



440.11  NO PARKING ZONE.



   The City, upon the recommendation of the Director of Public Safety, may
create no parking zones on public streets in order to prohibit vehicles from
parking within a portion of the public street that may otherwise be practical
for on-street parking.



(Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.12  BLOCKING A DRIVEWAY.



   It shall be unlawful to park a vehicle on a public street if the
location where the vehicle is parked blocks a driveway.



(Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.13  NOT PARKING WITHIN PARKING SPACES.



   In locations of the City where parking spaces are identified by
pavement markings placed by the City, it shall be unlawful to park a vehicle
in a manner so that it is not located within the defined parking space.



(Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.14  PARKING IN AN ALLEY.



   It shall be unlawful to park a vehicle in an alley and impede traffic
if the alley is signed for no parking.



(Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.15  PARKING IN FRONT YARD AND ON/OVER A SIDEWALK.



   (a)   No person shall park a vehicle, trailer, or watercraft in a
front yard within a residential district of the City, nor on or over any
public sidewalk.



   (b)   A "front yard" for the purpose of this section means that part
of a lot, other than a driveway, between the curb or the street line and the
front line of the main building on the lot, and for a corner lot, shall
include the part of the lot between the side of the building and the curb or
the street line.



   (c)   Vehicles may be parked temporarily in the front yard when
loading and unloading, or pursuant to a handicapper permit issued for that
purpose.



(Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.16  PARKING IN A PROHIBITED ZONE.



   In the interest of public safety, the City Council may from time to
time, through amendment of the violation schedule,  designate locations of a
public street where parking is prohibited.



(Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.17  PARKING FOR A PROHIBITED PURPOSE.



   In the interest of public safety, the City Council may from time to
time, through amendment of the violation schedule, identify certain
activities which are prohibited from occurring within parking lanes of a
public street and within a public parking lot.



(Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.18  AUTHORITY OF THE PUBLIC SAFETY DIRECTOR.



   The Public Safety Director shall possess such authority necessary to
designate on-street parking spaces for use by public safety officials only
(police, fire and ambulance services) in the Downtown District as he or she
may determine necessary.



(Ord. 448.  Passed 4-10-07.)



440.99  PENALTY; IMPOUNDING.



   (a)   Civil Infraction.  Whoever violates any of the provisions of
this chapter shall be liable for a civil infraction under Public Acts 510 and
511 of 1978, as amended.  Adjudication of liability for a violation of this
chapter shall be pursuant to Sections R 28.1101 through R 28.1110 of the
Michigan Administrative Code as of August 1, 1979, as amended, and Michigan
law pertaining to civil infractions.



   (b)   Violations.  Whoever parks in a parking zone in violation of
this chapter shall pay fees and penalties provided for in subsection (c)
hereof at the Ionia City Hall, 114 N. Kidd Street, Ionia, Michigan.
