facility, the Community Development Director shall require the owner and
licensee to provide information in writing to demonstrate any physical or
operational characteristics that are proposed to be altered under the new
owner, or a statement in writing that no physical or operational changes are
proposed.



   (b)   If changes to the approved site plan are proposed, a site plan
prepared according to the requirements of Chapter 1276 shall be submitted
that shows any proposed changes to the site plan.



   (c)   The proposed new owner shall provide proof of licensing by the
State of Michigan for the approved medical marihuana facility.



   (d)   The Community Development Director shall determine whether the
change in ownership and any proposed changes in the approved site plan, shall
require a public hearing and approval by the Planning Commission as required
by Section 1289.08(c) herein.



   (e)   The Community Development Director may, at his or her
discretion, approve the proposed change in ownership, and any changes
proposed to the site plan, without a public hearing.



   (f)   In no case shall an approved medial marihuana facility be
approved or used for a different type of medical marihuana facility except in
accordance with all requirements and procedures of this Chapter 1289.



   (g)   A change of location of a medical marihuana facility after
licensure requires a new license according to the requirements of the Medical
Marihuana Facilities Licensing Act, PA 281 of 2016, M.C.L.A. §§ 333.27101
et seq., as amended.  A change of location of a medical marihuana facility
after licensure, or a change of licensee at a location previously approved as
a medical marihuana facility, requires application for approval as a special
land use by the City of Ionia according to the requirements of this Chapter
1289.



(Ord. 539.  Passed 3-5-19.)



1289.12  VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.



   (a)   Any act or failure to act done in violation of the provisions
of this chapter is hereby declared to be a nuisance per se.



   (b)   A violation of this chapter is a municipal civil infraction
and shall be subject to the provisions of Section 202.99(b) of the Municipal
Code of the City of Ionia.



(Ord. 539.  Passed 3-5-19.)

I-A.  Notes To Schedule.




   (a)   See I-B below for Subdivision Open Space Plan, regarding
flexibility allowances.





   (b)   For all uses permitted other than single-family residential,
the setback shall equal the height of the main building or the setback
required in Section 1248.03 or Appendix I, whichever is greater.





   (c)   In the RM and RM-1 Multiple-Family Residential Districts, the
minimum distance between any two buildings shall be regulated according to
the length and height of such buildings, and in no instance shall this
distance be less than thirty feet.  Parking may be permitted within a
required side or rear yard, but shall not cover more than thirty percent of
the area of any required yard, or any minimum distance between the
buildings.  The formula regulating the required minimum distance between two
buildings in the RM and  RM-1 Districts is as follows:





S = LA + LB +2(HA + HB),





6




   where



 



      S =   Required minimum horizontal distance between any wall of
building A and any wall of building B or the vertical prolongation of either.



      LA = Total length of building A.



   The total length of building A is the length of that portion or
portions of a wall or walls of building A from which, when viewed directly
from above, the lines drawn perpendicular to building A will intersect any
wall of building B.



      LB = Total length of building B.



   The total length of building B is the length of that portion or
portions of a wall or walls of building B from which, when viewed directly
from above, the lines drawn perpendicular to building B will intersect any
wall of building A.



      HA = Height of building A.



   The height of building A at any given level is the height above natural
grade level of any portion or portions of a wall or walls along the length of
building A.  Natural grade level shall be the mean level of the ground
immediately adjoining the portion or portions of the wall or walls along the
total length of the building.



      HB = Height of building B.



   The height of building B at any given level is the height above natural
grade level of any portion or portions of a wall or walls along the length of
building B.  Natural grade level shall be the mean level of the ground
immediately adjoining the portion or portions of the wall or walls along the
total length of the building.  (See Appendix XI of this Zoning Code.)



   (d)   Reserved.



   (e)   No side yards are required along the interior side lot lines
of the District, except as otherwise specified in the Building and Housing
Code, provided that if walls of structures facing such interior side lot
lines contain windows, or other openings, side yards of not less than ten
feet shall be provided.



         On a corner lot which borders on a Residential District,
there shall be provided a setback of 20 feet on the side or residential
street.  On an exterior side yard abutting a Residential District or
abutting a street, there shall be provided a setback of ten feet in width.



   (f)   No building shall be closer than 75 feet to the outer
perimeter (property line) of the District, or to any major thoroughfare.



   (g)   No building shall be located closer than 50 feet to the outer
perimeter (property line) of the District when said property line abuts any
Residential District.



   (h)   All storage shall be in the side yard or rear yard and shall
be completely screened with an obscuring wall or fence, not less than six
feet high, or with a chain-link type fence and a green belt planting so as to
obscure all view from any adjacent residential, office or business district
or from a public street.



   (i)   A minimum distance of 45 feet shall be provided from the
centerline of any main access service drive or from any service drive serving
more than one four-unit building.



(1975 Code § 5.102) (Ord. 251.  Passed 11-9-76; Ord. 323.  Passed 7-5-88;
Ord. 341.  Passed 11-13-90; Ord. 08-2002-04.  Passed 9-3-02; Ord. 518. 
Passed 3-3-15.)



   I-B.  Subdivision Open Space Plan.



   (a)   The intent of the Subdivision Open Space Plan is to promote
the following objectives.



      (1)   Provide a more desirable living environment by
preserving the natural character of open fields, stands of trees, brooks,
hills and similar natural assets.



      (2)   Encourage developers to use a more creative approach in
the development of residential areas.



      (3)   Encourage a more efficient, aesthetic and desirable use
of open area, while recognizing a reduction in development costs, by allowing
the developer to by-pass natural obstacles on the site.



      (4)   Encourage the provision of open space within a
reasonable distance from all lot development of the subdivision and further
encourage the development of recreational facilities.



   (b)   Modifications to the standards as outlined in the Schedule of
Regulations, may be made in the One-Family Residential Districts when the
following conditions are met:



      (1)   The area of lots in the R-2 and R-3 One-Family
Residential Districts which are served by a public sanitary sewer system may
be reduced up to ten percent.  In the R-2 and R-3 Districts this reduction
may be accomplished in part by reducing lot widths up to ten feet.  These
lot area reductions shall be permitted, provided that dwelling unit density
shall be no greater than if the land area to be subdivided were developed in
the minimum square foot lot areas as required for each One-Family District
under the Schedule of Regulations.  All calculations shall be predicated
upon the One-Family Districts having the following gross densities (including
roads):



   R-1 – 4.1 dwelling units per acre;



   R-2 – 2.7 dwelling units per acre;



   R-3 – 1.6 dwelling units per acre.



      (2)   Rear yards may be reduced to thirty feet when such lots
border on land dedicated for parks, recreation, and/or open space purposes,
provided that the width of said dedicated land shall not be less than 100
feet measured at the point at which it abuts the rear yard of the adjacent
lot.



      (3)   Under the provisions of paragraph (b)(1) hereof, for
each square foot of land gained within a residential subdivision through the
reduction of lot size below the minimum requirements as outlined in the
Schedule of Regulations, at least equal amounts of land shall be dedicated to
the common use of the lot owners of the subdivision in a manner approved by
the City.



      (4)   The area to be dedicated for subdivision open space
purposes shall in no instance be less than four acres and shall be in a
location and shape approved by the Planning Commission.



      (5)   The land area necessary to meet the minimum requirements
of Section I-B shall not include bodies of water, swamps or land with
excessive grades making it unsuitable for recreation.  All land dedicated
shall be so graded and developed as to have natural drainage.  The entire
area may, however, be located in a floodplain.



      (6)   This plan, for reduced lot sizes, shall be permitted
only if it is mutually agreeable to the legislative body and the subdivider
or developer.



      (7)   This plan, for reduced lot sizes, shall be started
within six months after having received approval of the final plat, and must
be completed in a reasonable time.  Failure to start within this period
shall void all previous approval.



      (8)   Under this planned unit approach, the developer or
subdivider shall dedicate the total park area on all or any portion of the
plat at the time of filing of the final plat.



(1975 Code §5.104)

1421.01  TRANSFERRING OF RESPONSIBILITIES.



   Pursuant to the provisions of Section 8b(7) of the State Construction
Code Act of 1972, as amended, the City hereby transfers responsibility for
the administration and enforcement of its Building Code, Mechanical Code,
Plumbing Code and Electrical Code provisions to the County of Ionia.



(Ord. 470.  Passed 1-5-10.)



1421.02  EFFECTIVE DATE OF TRANSFER.



   The effective date of the transferring of responsibilities for the
administration and enforcement of the Building Code, Mechanical Code,
Plumbing Code and Electrical Code shall be January 11, 2010.



(Ord. 470.  Passed 1-5-10.)

TITLE FOUR – Miscellaneous Building Regulations



   Chap. 1448.  Numbering of Buildings.



   Chap. 1450.  Permits and Fees.

Chapter 1448
Numbering of Buildings



1448.01   Numbering required.



1448.02   Responsibility of owners and occupants; specifications.



1448.99   Penalty.



   CROSS REFERENCES



   Subdivision Control Law - see M.C.L.A. §§ 560.101 et seq.



1448.01  NUMBERING REQUIRED.



   (a)   All premises shall bear a distinctive street number on the
front thereof, at or near the front entrance of said premises, in accordance
with and as designated upon the street map on file in the office of the
Building Inspector.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94.)



1448.02  RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNERS AND OCCUPANTS; SPECIFICATIONS.



   The owners and occupants of all buildings in the City shall cause the
correct numbers to be placed thereon in accordance with the street map. 
Such numbers shall be not less than three inches high, shall be facing the
street and adjacent to the principal entrance, and in such position as to be
plainly visible from the street.



(Ord. 362.  Passed 3-1-94.)



1448.99  PENALTY.



   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  See Section 202.99 of these Codified Ordinances for
the general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)



Chapter 1450
Permits and Fees



EDITOR'S NOTE:  There are no sections in Chapter 1450.  This chapter has
been established to provide a place for cross references and any future
legislation.



   CROSS REFERENCES

Chapter 1456
Smoke Detectors and Fire Extinguishers



1456.01   Installation of detectors and extinguishers required; rental
unit defined.



1456.02   Location of detectors; sleeping area and owner defined.



1456.03   Use of fire detection systems as alternative.



1456.04   Approval of equipment by Fire Chief.



1456.05   Installation specifications.



1456.06   Changes in occupancy.



1456.07   Inspections.



1456.08   Supplemental standards.



1456.09   Placement of fire extinguishers.



1456.10   Use of battery-type and electric plug-in detectors.



1456.11   Responsibility of corporations and partnerships.



1456.99   Penalty.



   CROSS REFERENCES



   Fire prevention fees - see ADM. 214.08



   Compliance with fire regulations required for licensing - see B. R. &
T. 802.09



   Use of fire hydrants - see S.U. & P.S. 1040.21



   Burning of garbage and rubbish - see S.U. & P.S. 1060.05(a)



   International Fire Prevention Code - see F.P. Ch. 1610



1456.01  INSTALLATION OF DETECTORS AND EXTINGUISHERS REQUIRED; RENTAL UNIT
DEFINED.



   (a)   It shall be the responsibility of the owner of each new and
existing rental unit within the City of Ionia to install smoke detectors in
each such rental unit as is hereinafter provided.  It shall also be the
responsibility of the owner of each new and existing rental unit in the City
of Ionia to provide fire extinguishers as is hereinafter provided.  Smoke
detectors shall be capable of sensing visible particles of combustion and
providing a suitable audible alarm thereof; further, they shall be installed
by the first day of April, in the manner hereinafter provided, and thereafter
maintained in working order in compliance with this chapter.  Failure to
install smoke detectors as is required under this chapter will subject the
owner of any such rental unit to the penalties set forth in Section 1456.99
hereof.



   (b)   As used in this chapter, "rental unit" means a residence
apartment, flat, motel room, hotel room, boarding room or boarding house, for
which consideration is paid by one person to another for use or occupancy
thereof.



(Ord. 287.  Passed 3-2-82.)



1456.02  LOCATION OF DETECTORS; SLEEPING AREA AND OWNER DEFINED.



   (a)   At least one smoke detector shall be installed to protect each
sleeping area.  A sleeping area is defined as the area or areas of the
family living unit in which the bedrooms (or sleeping rooms) are separated by
other use areas (such as kitchens or living rooms, but not bathrooms or
closets).  They shall be considered as separate sleeping areas for the
purpose of this chapter.



   (b)   At least one smoke detector shall be installed at the head
(top) of each stairway leading up to an occupied area in such a manner as to
assure that rising smoke is not obstructed in reaching the detector and that
the detector intercepts rising smoke before it reaches the sleeping area.



   (c)   Owner is defined as the person who holds legal title to the
premises.  However, should a land contract be in existence and recorded with
the Ionia County Register of Deeds, or should an affidavit or memorandum as
to the existence of a land contract be recorded with the Ionia County
Register of Deeds, then the land contract purchaser shall be considered the
owner for purposes of this chapter.



(Ord. 287.  Passed 3-2-82.)



1456.03  USE OF FIRE DETECTION SYSTEMS AS ALTERNATIVE.



   As an alternative to self-contained smoke detectors, an approved fire
detection system may be installed and maintained.  Each fire detection
system must be individually approved and a permit issued therefor by the Fire
Chief or his or her designee. 



(Ord. 287.  Passed 3-2-82.)



1456.04  APPROVAL OF EQUIPMENT BY FIRE CHIEF.



   (a)   All devices, combinations of devices and equipment required
herein must be installed in conformance with this chapter.  The Fire Chief
shall prepare a list of approved smoke detector devices and a list of
approved fire extinguisher devices and equipment, which list may be
subsequently amended by the Fire Chief as necessary.  Such approval shall be
permanent unless the Fire Chief subsequently finds that the equipment is
hazardous or unreliable, in which case the Fire Chief may suspend or revoke
approval.  The Fire Chief may, in such case, determine whether replacement
of an existing installation shall be required.  The list of approved smoke
detectors and/or fire extinguishers shall be kept at the office of the City
Clerk for the City of Ionia and at the office of the Fire Chief for the City
of Ionia and shall be made available upon request to any person if request is
made by mail or person at either office.



(Ord. 287.  Passed 3-2-82.)



1456.05  INSTALLATION SPECIFICATIONS.



   (a)   As used in this section, "new" means constructed or built
after the effective date of this chapter.



   (b)   In new rental units or apartment buildings, at least one smoke
detector in each apartment or dwelling unit shall be wired directly (hard
wired) to the building's power supply.  Other smoke detectors required
hereunder may be alarms which meet the requirements of Section 1456.10.



   (c)   In existing rental units and/or apartment buildings, smoke
detectors may be hard wired or may be battery operated or powered by electric
plug if the same comply with Section 1456.10.



   (d)   In new hotels or motels, smoke detectors in hallways,
stairways, common areas and storage areas must be wired directly (hard wired)
to the building's power supply. In such individual hotel or motel sleeping
rooms, one smoke detector must be provided, either hard wired or powered in
conformance with Section 1456.10.



   (e)   In existing hotels, motels, boarding rooms or boarding houses,
smoke detectors must be provided in hallways, stairways, common areas and
storage areas.  Such smoke detectors may be wired directly (hard wired) to
the building's power supply or in conformance with Section 1456.10.  In any
existing hotel, motel, boarding house or boarding room in which the building
or any part thereof is renovated in a major renovation project (defined as a
project equal in cost to ten or more of the buildings' State equalized
value), the smoke detectors in the hallways, stairways, common areas and
storage areas shall be hard wired.



(Ord. 287.  Passed 3-2-82.)



1456.06  CHANGES IN OCCUPANCY.



   (a)   After April 1, 1982, whenever there is a change of occupancy
in a dwelling unit in the City of Ionia, occasioned by or incidental to a
sale, lease or sublease of a rental unit, it shall be the duty of the grantor
thereof (i.e., the seller, lessor or sublessor, as the case may be) to
certify, in writing before occupancy, to the new occupant, that all smoke
detectors as required by this chapter are installed and in proper working
condition.  Failure to comply with this subsection shall be punishable as a
misdemeanor as is provided herein and shall be evidence of the negligence of
or inattention of the grantor.  This subsection shall not, however, render
any lease, contract or sublease void for failure to have certification
required hereby.



   (b)   The occupant of a rental unit shall not remove the battery
from a smoke detector or in any way put a smoke detector out of working
order.  The occupant of a rental unit shall not, upon termination or
expiration of his or her lease or rental contract, take any such detector for
his or her own use.  A landlord, upon a change of occupancy, who discovers
that a smoke detector has been tampered with in any way, or has been taken,
shall report it to the Ionia Fire Chief, upon discovery, and have him or her
witness the damage or missing detector(s).  This will be punishable as a
misdemeanor as is provided herein and shall be evidence of negligence.



(Ord. 287.  Passed 3-2-82.)



1456.07  INSPECTIONS.



   The Fire Chief or his or her designee may, at any time, inspect any
device or installation which is required by this chapter.



(Ord. 287.  Passed 3-2-82.)



1456.08  SUPPLEMENTAL STANDARDS.



   This chapter is intended to be used with and as a supplement to all
construction and fire codes in effect within the City of Ionia.



(Ord. 287.  Passed 3-2-82.)



1456.09  PLACEMENT OF FIRE EXTINGUISHERS.



   In hotels, motels or residential hotels, all the following regulations
shall apply to the placement of fire extinguishers instead of the requirement
that a fire extinguisher be placed in each room:



   (a)   There shall be a minimum of two extinguishers per floor
located in an accessible hallway area.



   (b)   There shall be a minimum of one extinguisher for each five
rental units.



   (c)   There shall be a placement of a fire extinguisher every fifty
feet per hallway and per floor or story.



(Ord. 287.  Passed 3-2-82.)



1456.10  USE OF BATTERY-TYPE AND ELECTRIC PLUG-IN DETECTORS.



   (a)   Battery-type smoke detectors may be used if the batteries are
mounted to assure that the following conditions are met:



      (1)   All power requirements are met for at least one year's
life, including weekly testing.



      (2)   A distinctive audible trouble signal is given before the
battery is incapable of operating (from aging, terminal corrosion, etc.) for
alarm purposes.



      (3)   For a unit employing a lock-in alarm feature, automatic
transfer is provided from alarm to a trouble condition.



      (4)   The unit is capable of producing an alarm signal for at
least four minutes at the battery voltage at which a trouble signal is
normally obtained followed by seven days of trouble signal operation.



      (5)   The audible trouble signal is produced at least once
every minute for seven consecutive days.



      (6)   The monitored batteries meeting these specifications are
clearly identified on the unit near the battery compartment.



   (b)   Electric, plug-in smoke detectors may be used and operated
from a wall plug if the plug is fitted with a plug restraining device and if
the wall outlet power supply is not controlled by a switch other than the
main power supply.



(Ord. 287.  Passed 3-2-82.)



1456.11  RESPONSIBILITY OF CORPORATIONS AND PARTNERSHIPS.



   Any officer of any corporation or any partner of any partnership found
to be in violation of this chapter shall be subject to serve a jail sentence
or pay a fine as provided for in Section 1456.99.



(Ord. 287.  Passed 3-2-82.)



1456.99  PENALTY.



(EDITOR'S NOTE:  See Section 202.99 of these Codified Ordinances for the
general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)



TITLE SIX – Housing



   Chap. 1460.  International Property Maintenance Code.



Chapter 1460
International Property Maintenance Code



1460.01   2012 edition adopted; purpose.



1460.02   File and distribution copies.



1460.03   Enforcement.



1460.04   Conflicts of laws.



1460.05   Amendments.



1460.99   Penalty.



   CROSS REFERENCES



   Dilapidation of dwellings and nuisances - see CHTR. § 12.02



   State Housing Code - see M.C.L.A. §§ 125.401 et seq.



   Municipal Housing Act - see M.C.L.A. §§ 125.651 et seq.



   Municipal housing commissions - see M.C.L.A. §§ 125.653 et seq.



   Adoption, promulgation and publication of rules - see M.C.L.A. §
125.694b



   Board of Tenant Affairs - see M.C.L.A. §§ 125.699 et seq.

125.731 et seq.



   Hotels, boarding and lodging houses - see M.C.L.A. §§ 427.1 et seq.



1460.01  2012 EDITION ADOPTED; PURPOSE.



   Pursuant to Section 2.15 of the City Charter, the International
Property Maintenance Code, the 2012 edition, as promulgated by the
International Code Council, Inc., is hereby adopted as the official Property
Maintenance Code of the City for establishing minimum legal requirements for
the maintenance of buildings, dwellings, structures and premises as therein
provided.  Each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties,
conditions and terms of the International Property Maintenance Code are
hereby referred to, adopted and made a part of this chapter by reference as
if fully set out in this chapter, save and except such portions as may be
hereinafter amended or repealed.



(Ord. 489.  Passed 6-7-11; Ord. 523.  Passed 7-7-15.)



1460.02  FILE AND DISTRIBUTION COPIES.



   At least one copy of the International Property Maintenance Code, as
adopted in Section 1460.01, is on file with the City Clerk for inspection by
the public.



(Ord. 523.  Passed 7-7-15.)



1460.03  ENFORCEMENT.



   The City Manager, or his or her designee, is hereby authorized and
directed to administer and enforce the International Property Maintenance
Code within the corporate limits of the City.



(Ord. 523.  Passed 7-7-15.)



1460.04  CONFLICTS OF LAWS.



   (a)   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of
the International Property Maintenance Code, as adopted in Section 1460.01,
and a provision of State law, the State law shall control.



   (b)   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of
the International Property Maintenance Code, as adopted in Section 1460.01,
and a provision of a local ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation, the
local provision shall control.



   (c)   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of
the International Property Maintenance Code, as adopted in Section 1460.01,
and a provision of any other technical code adopted by the City by reference,
the stricter standard shall control.



(Ord. 523.  Passed 7-7-15.)



1460.05  AMENDMENTS.



   The International Property Maintenance Code, as adopted in Section
1460.01, is hereby amended as follows:



   (a)   Section 101.1.  Insert:   “City of Ionia, Michigan.”



   (b)   Section 103.5.  Insert:   “Fees. The fees for activities
and services performed by the City in carrying out its responsibilities under
this Code shall be as set forth in Chapter 214 of the Administration Code of
the Codified Ordinances of the City of Ionia (the General Fee Schedule), or
as otherwise provided by Council from time to time.”



   (c)   Section 112.4.  Insert:   “Any person who shall continue
any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as
that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition,
shall be liable for a fine of not less than $100.00 or more than $500.00.”



   (d)   Section 302.4.  Insert:   “All premises and exterior
property shall be maintained free from grass, weeds or undergrowth higher or
longer than six inches subject to the following exceptions:



      (1)   On portions of undeveloped property behind a wooded tree
line.



      (2)   On portions of undeveloped lands more than 25 feet from
a public sidewalk or street open to the public.



      (3)   On portions of undeveloped platted lots more than 25
feet from a public sidewalk or street open to the public and from a
neighboring lot line.”



   (e)   Section 304.14.  Insert:   “During the period from April
15th to November 15th, every door, window and other outside opening required
for ventilation of habitable rooms, food preparation areas, food service
areas or any areas where products to be included or utilized in food for
human consumption are processed, manufactured, packaged or stored shall be
supplied with approved tightly fitting screens of minimum 16 mesh per inch
(16 mesh per 25 mm), and every screen door used for insect control shall have
a self-closing device in good working order.”



   (f)   Section 602.3.  Insert:   “...shall supply heat during
the period from November 15 to April 15...”



   (g)   Section 602.4.  Insert:   “...shall be supplied with
heat during the period from November 15 to April 15...”



(Ord. 489.  Passed 6-7-11; Ord. 523.  Passed 7-7-15.)



1460.99  PENALTY.



   A violation of any section of this chapter shall be considered a civil
infraction for which fines are established in Section 202.99 of these
Codified Ordinances.



(Ord. 523.  Passed 7-7-15.)

Chapter 1610
International Fire Prevention Code



1610.01   2012 edition adopted.



1610.02   Purpose.



1610.03   File and distribution copies.



1610.04   Conflicts of laws.



1610.05   Amendments.

   CROSS REFERENCES

1610.01  2012 EDITION ADOPTED.



   Pursuant to Section 2.15 of the City Charter, there is hereby adopted
by and for the City the International Fire Prevention Code, being
particularly the 2012 edition thereof, including Appendix Chapters,
promulgated by International Code Council, Inc., save and except such
portions thereof as may be hereinafter amended or deleted.



(Ord. 522.  Passed 7-7-15.)



1610.02  PURPOSE.



   The purpose of the International Fire Prevention Code, as adopted in
Section 1610.01, is to establish rules and regulations for the control of
buildings, structures and premises as therein provided.



(Ord. 522.  Passed 7-7-15.)



1610.03  FILE AND DISTRIBUTION COPIES.



   At least one copy of the International Fire Prevention Code, as adopted
in Section 1610.01, is on file with the City Clerk for inspection by the
public.



(Ord. 522.  Passed 7-7-15.)



1610.04  CONFLICTS OF LAWS.



   (a)   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of
the International Fire Prevention Code, as adopted in Section 1610.01, and a
provision of State law, the State law shall control.



   (b)   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of
the International Fire Prevention Code, as adopted in Section 1610.01, and a
provision of a local ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation, the local
provision shall control.



   (c)   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of
the International Fire Prevention Code, as adopted in Section 1610.01, and a
provision of any other technical code adopted by the City by reference, the
stricter standard shall control.



(Ord. 522.  Passed 7-7-15.)



1610.05  AMENDMENTS.



   The International Fire Prevention Code, as adopted in Section 1610.01,
is hereby amended as follows:



   Section 101.1.   Insert:   “City of Ionia, Michigan.”



   Section 108.1.   Insert at the end of the Section:



            “The City’s Housing Board of Appeals shall act as
the Board of Appeals established in Section 108.1.”



   Section 109.4.   Shall be revised to read:



            “Persons who shall violate a provision of this code
or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall
erect, install, alter, repair or do work in violation of the approved
construction documents or directive of the fire code official, or of a permit
or certificate used under provisions of this code, shall be subject to the
penalty provided in Section 202.99 of the Codified Ordinances of Ionia.”



   Section 111.4.   Shall be revised to read:



            “Any person who shall continue to work after having
been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is
directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be
subject to the penalty provided in Section 202.99 of the Codified Ordinances
of Ionia.”



(Ord. 522.  Passed 7-7-15.)



1610.06  LIMITS ON STORAGE OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS.



   The limits referred to in certain sections of the International Fire
Code are hereby established as follows:



   Section 5704.2.9.6.1.   (limits in which the storage of Class I and
Class II liquids in above- ground tanks outside of buildings is prohibited):
all areas which are zoned either residential or commercial.



   Section 5706.2.4.4.   (limits in which the storage of Class I and
Class II liquids in above- ground tanks is prohibited): all areas which are
zoned either residential or commercial.



   Section 6104.2.   (limits in which the storage of liquefied
petroleum gas is restricted for the protection of heavily populated or
congested areas):  all areas which are zoned either residential or
commercial.



(Ord. 522.  Passed 7-7-15.)



1610.99  PENALTY; EQUITABLE REMEDIES.



   A violation of any section of this chapter shall be considered a civil
infraction for which fines are established in Section 202.99 of these
Codified Ordinances.



(Ord. 522.  Passed 7-7-15.)



CHAPTER 1612
Reimbursement Fund for Fire Response



1612.01   Definitions.



1612.02   Cost summary report.



1612.03   Insurance reimbursement.



1612.04   Property fires.



1612.05   Rescue response.



1612.06   Use of monies.



1612.07   Hardships; no insurance coverage.



1612.08   Alcohol crashes.



1612.09   Hazardous materials.



1612.01  DEFINITIONS.



   As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings given to them herein:



   (a)   "Costs" shall mean the actual costs incurred by the Department
of Public Safety in responding to a fire incident. Costs shall include, but
not be limited to: firefighter time; foam application; hourly costs for fire
response vehicles; hourly costs for ancillary firefighting equipment; and
administrative charges such as FICA, pension, unemployment, and workmen's
compensation.



   (b)   "Effective firefighting force" shall mean the number of
personnel required under the adopted Standards of Cover for the Department of
Public Safety.



   (c)   "Fire department" shall mean the Ionia Department of Public
Safety



   (d)   "Fire response" shall mean any call for service that requires
response of fire fighting units of the Department of Public Safety.



   (e)   "Rescue" shall mean any call requiring response of the
Incident Response Unit and Jaws of Life Equipment.



   (f)   "Standard of cover" shall mean the adopted protocol and
response strategy based on a comprehensive risk assessment done by and for
the Department of Public Safety.



   (g)   "Total reflex time" shall mean the time computation beginning
with the initial call for service to the time of arrival of fire units.



(Ord. 03-2004-01.  Passed 7-6-04.)



1612.02  COST SUMMARY REPORT.



   When responding to calls for service, the Department of Public Safety
shall compile a cost summary report for each and every call based upon the
following costs:



   (a)   Per hour cost of responding vehicles;



   (b)   Per hour cost of responding members of the agency;



   (c)   Cost of hand tools and ancillary equipment based upon national
standards;



   (d)   Cost of fringe benefits such as FICA, unemployment, workmen's
compensation, pension, etc.



   (e)   Depreciation costs of any equipment; and



   (f)   Hourly fees of other costs such as administration, etc.



(Ord. 03-2004-01.  Passed 7-6-04.)



1612.03  INSURANCE REIMBURSEMENT.



   Following compilation of all fees and costs for a fire response, such
billing report shall be sent to the insurance agency for the affected
property seeking reimbursement.



(Ord. 03-2004-01.  Passed 7-6-04.)



1612.04  PROPERTY FIRES.



   In the case of property fires, the fee for response shall not exceed
five hundred dollars ($500.00). However, the actual costs for the run shall
become part of the fire response report and shall be used to determine actual
costs for service on a year-to-year basis.



(Ord. 03-2004-01.  Passed 7-6-04.)



1612.05  RESCUE RESPONSE.



   In the case of rescue response, the costs incurred shall be billed to
the insurance agency for the party requiring the use of such services.



(Ord. 03-2004-01.  Passed 7-6-04.)



1612.06  USE OF MONIES.



   All monies received for fire response shall be credited to the
Department of Public Safety for use in replacing equipment, foam, training,
and other department costs. It shall not be used for General Fund purposes or
miscellaneous expenses.



(Ord. 03-2004-01.  Passed 7-6-04.)



1612.07  HARDSHIPS; NO INSURANCE COVERAGE.



   (a)   The City recognizes that hardship cases and lack of or
underinsurance shall occur in responding to fires and calls for services. In
most cases, these hardships shall be directly attributable to the
unavailability of insurance coverage for losses.



   (b)   In such cases, the fire victim shall fill out a form available
at City Hall, attesting that he/she/they have no insurance and that paying a
response fee would pose a considerable and unmanageable hardship on them
given the financial loss they have incurred as a result of the incident.



   (c)   The Director shall verify that the party does not have
insurance and may issue a waiver of billing in such cases. In all cases of a
waiver, the costs shall be tallied for the yearly cost report but the pursuit
of billing shall end with the presentation to the property owner.



   (d)   All hardship costs shall be borne by the municipality in which
the property is located and shall be taken from the General Fund of the unit.



(Ord. 03-2004-01.  Passed 7-6-04.)



1612.08  ALCOHOL CRASHES.



   In the case of vehicular accidents in excess of the legal limits for
alcohol, and upon conviction of the alcohol related offense, all associated
costs of the Department of Public Safety shall be billed to the party
involved. In such cases, if the party does not pay the associated costs, they
shall be forwarded to the court having jurisdiction for restitution as part
of any legal settlement.



(Ord. 03-2004-01.  Passed 7-6-04.)



1612.09  HAZARDOUS MATERIALS.



   In the case of any call to respond to a hazardous materials call, the
party causing such release shall sign a "Notice of Liability" form that shall
require all associated response costs to be paid. In no case shall a waiver
be granted for hazardous material response. Included in costs are the costs
of the Department of Public Safety, Emergency Management (City and/or
County), mutual aid departments, and any professional agency required to
contain and clear the incident.  Failure to pay the liability may result in
prosecution both criminally and civilly for the response.



(Ord. 03-2004-01.  Passed 7-6-04.)



CHAPTER 1614
Burning



1614.01   Prohibition.



1614.02   Burning of waste products.



1614.03   Recreational fire.



1614.99   Penalty.



1614.01  PROHIBITION.



   Outdoor burning in the City not specifically authorized by this chapter
is prohibited.



(Ord. 505.  Passed 8-6-13.)



1614.02  BURNING OF WASTE PRODUCTS.



   The outdoor burning of trash, leaves, building materials, tires and
petroleum products within the City is prohibited.



(Ord. 505.  Passed 8-6-13.)



1614.03  RECREATIONAL FIRE.



   These regulations apply to recreational fires in the City:



   (a)   Cooking fires, camp fires and recreational fires are
permitted.  All such fires must be contained within in area four feet or
less in diameter and three feet or less in height in a fire pit, in an above
ground commercially manufactured fire receptacle or in a masonry fireplace
made for outdoor burning.



   (b)   No burning is allowed from 1:00 am to 6:00 am.



   (c)   Except for the use of receptacles or fireplaces described in
division (a), any burning shall occur at least 25 feet from an existing
structure and property line and shall be at the rear of any property, away
from any street and sidewalk.  In the event the dimensions of a lot are such
that they will not permit compliance with this requirement, then the burning
shall occur as close to the center of the property as is practicable behind
the dwelling, an equal distance from the property line and the building.



   (d)   All burning shall occur under the supervision of an adult who
shall remain present at the fire and shall at all times be responsible for
controlling the fire and insuring that neither life nor property is
endangered.



   (e)   No burning shall be permitted nor be allowed to continue where
wind conditions exceed ten miles per hour or in any case where wind
conditions create or are likely to create a nuisance or endanger persons or
the property of anyone.



   (f)   A fire which endangers or becomes offensive to other persons
or harmful to their property is a nuisance and shall promptly be extinguished.



(Ord. 505.  Passed 8-6-13.)



1614.99  PENALTY.



   A violation of any section of this chapter shall be considered a civil
infraction for which fines are established in Section 202.99 of these
Codified Ordinances.



(Ord. 505.  Passed 8-6-13.)
